standard_metadata.standard_description: Give examples of linear equations in one variable with one solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solutions. Show which of these possibilities is the case by successively transforming the given equation into simpler forms, until an equivalent equation of the form x = a, a = a, or a = b results (where a and b are different numbers).
standard_metadata.standard_title: Number of solutions to equations challenge

question.content: **Which of the following equations have exactly one solution?**

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have exactly one solution, $\blueD{a}$ must be different from $\maroonD{c}$.
In the following equation, $\blueD{a}$ is different from $\maroonD{c}$.   * $\blueD2x-31=\maroonD{-2}x-31$    So, the equation has exactly one solution.
The answer:  * $\blueD2x-31=\maroonD{-2}x-31$

question.content: **Which of the following equations have exactly one solution?**

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have exactly one solution, $\blueD{a}$ must be different from $\maroonD{c}$.
In the following equations, $\blueD{a}$ is different from $\maroonD{c}$.   * $\blueD{19}x+18=\maroonD{-19}x+18$ * $\blueD{19}x-18=\maroonD{-19}x+18$    So, the equations have exactly one solution.
The answer:  * $\blueD{19}x+18=\maroonD{-19}x+18$ * $\blueD{19}x-18=\maroonD{-19}x+18$

question.content: **Which of the following equations have exactly one solution?**

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have exactly one solution, $\blueD{a}$ must be different from $\maroonD{c}$.

In the following equations, $\blueD{a}$ is different from $\maroonD{c}$.   * $\blueD{-5}x+12=\maroonD{5}x-5$ *  $\blueD{-5}x+12=\maroonD{-12}x-12$ *  $\blueD{-5}x+12=\maroonD{5}x+12$     So, the equations have exactly one solution.
The answer:  * $\blueD{-5}x+12=\maroonD{5}x-5$ *  $\blueD{-5}x+12=\maroonD{-12}x-12$ *  $\blueD{-5}x+12=\maroonD{5}x+12$

question.content: **Which of the following equations have exactly one solution?**

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have exactly one solution, $\blueD{a}$ must be different from $\maroonD{c}$.

In the following equations, $\blueD{a}$ is different from $\maroonD{c}$.   * $\blueD{-13}x+12=\maroonD{13}x-13$ * $\blueD{12}x+12=\maroonD{13}x-12$ * $\blueD{-13}x+12=\maroonD{13}x+13$ * $\blueD{12}x+12=\maroonD{13}x+12$    So, the equations have exactly one solution.
The answer:  * $\blueD{-13}x+12=\maroonD{13}x-13$ * $\blueD{12}x+12=\maroonD{13}x-12$ * $\blueD{-13}x+12=\maroonD{13}x+13$ * $\blueD{12}x+12=\maroonD{13}x+12$

question.content: **Which of the following equations have exactly one solution?**

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have exactly one solution, $\blueD{a}$ must be different from $\maroonD{c}$.
In the following equations, $\blueD{a}$ is different from $\maroonD{c}$.   * $\blueD{-103}x-6=\maroonD{-6}x-103$ * $\blueD{-6}x-6=\maroonD{103}x-103$    So, the equations have exactly one solution.
The answer:  * $\blueD{-103}x-6=\maroonD{-6}x-103$ * $\blueD{-6}x-6=\maroonD{103}x-103$

question.content: **Which of the following equations have exactly one solution?**

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have exactly one solution, $\blueD{a}$ must be different from $\maroonD{c}$.

In the following equations, $\blueD{a}$ is different from $\maroonD{c}$.   * $\blueD{58}x+52=\maroonD{-78}x-78$ * $\blueD{58}x+52=\maroonD{78}x-78$ * $\blueD{-78}x+52=\maroonD{-52}x-78$    So, the equations have exactly one solution.
The answer:  * $\blueD{58}x+52=\maroonD{-78}x-78$ * $\blueD{58}x+52=\maroonD{78}x-78$ * $\blueD{-78}x+52=\maroonD{-52}x-78$

question.content: **Which of the following equations have exactly one solution?**

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have exactly one solution, $\blueD{a}$ must be different from $\maroonD{c}$.
In the following equation, $\blueD{a}$ is different from $\maroonD{c}$.   * $\blueD{6}x-6=\maroonD{15}x+15$    So, the equation has exactly one solution.
The answer:  * $\blueD{6}x-6=\maroonD{15}x+15$

question.content: **Which of the following equations have no solutions?**

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have no solutions, $\blueD{a}$ must be equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ must be different from $\goldE{d}$.

In the following equation, $\blueD{a}$ is equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ is different from $\goldE{d}$.  * $\blueD{14}x\greenD{+23}=\maroonD{14}x\goldE{-23}$    So, the equation has  no solutions.
The answer:  * $\blueD{14}x\greenD{+23}=\maroonD{14}x\goldE{-23}$

question.content: **Which of the following equations have no solutions?**

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have no solutions, $\blueD{a}$ must be equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ must be different from $\goldE{d}$.

In the following equations, $\blueD{a}$ is equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ is different from $\goldE{d}$.  * $\blueD{-4}x\greenD{+5}=\maroonD{-4}x\goldE{-4}$ * $\blueD{-4}x\greenD{+5}=\maroonD{-4}x\goldE{-5}$    So, the equations have no solutions.
The answer:  * $\blueD{-4}x\greenD{+5}=\maroonD{-4}x\goldE{-4}$ * $\blueD{-4}x\greenD{+5}=\maroonD{-4}x\goldE{-5}$

question.content: **Which of the following equations have no solutions?**

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have no solutions, $\blueD{a}$ must be equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ must be different from $\goldE{d}$.

In the following equations, $\blueD{a}$ is equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ is different from $\goldE{d}$.  *  $\blueD{33}x\greenD{+33}=\maroonD{33}x\goldE{+25}$ *  $\blueD{33}x\greenD{-25}=\maroonD{33}x\goldE{+25}$ *   $\blueD{33}x\greenD{-33}=\maroonD{33}x\goldE{+25}$    So, the equations have no solutions.
The answer:  *  $\blueD{33}x\greenD{+33}=\maroonD{33}x\goldE{+25}$ *  $\blueD{33}x\greenD{-25}=\maroonD{33}x\goldE{+25}$ *   $\blueD{33}x\greenD{-33}=\maroonD{33}x\goldE{+25}$

question.content: **Which of the following equations have no solutions?**

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have no solutions, $\blueD{a}$ must be equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ must be different from $\goldE{d}$.

In the following equations, $\blueD{a}$ is equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ is different from $\goldE{d}$.  * $\blueD{29}x\greenD{+11}=\maroonD{29}x\goldE{-11}$ * $\blueD{29}x\greenD{+29}=\maroonD{29}x\goldE{-11}$ * $\blueD{29}x\greenD{+92}=\maroonD{29}x\goldE{-11}$ * $\blueD{29}x\greenD{-29}=\maroonD{29}x\goldE{-11}$    So, the equations have  no solutions.

The answer:  * $\blueD{29}x\greenD{+11}=\maroonD{29}x\goldE{-11}$ * $\blueD{29}x\greenD{+29}=\maroonD{29}x\goldE{-11}$ * $\blueD{29}x\greenD{+92}=\maroonD{29}x\goldE{-11}$ * $\blueD{29}x\greenD{-29}=\maroonD{29}x\goldE{-11}$

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have no solutions, $\blueD{a}$ must be equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ must be different from $\goldE{d}$.

In the following equation, $\blueD{a}$ is equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ is different from $\goldE{d}$.  * $\blueD{15}x\greenD{-45}=\maroonD{15}x\goldE{+75}$    So, the equation has no solutions.
The answer:  * $\blueD{15}x\greenD{-45}=\maroonD{15}x\goldE{+75}$

In the following equations, $\blueD{a}$ is equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ is different from $\goldE{d}$.  * $\blueD{40}x\greenD{+40}=\maroonD{40}x\goldE{+20}$ * $\blueD{-20}x\greenD{+40}=\maroonD{-20}x\goldE{+20}$    So, the equations have no solutions.
The answer:  * $\blueD{40}x\greenD{+40}=\maroonD{40}x\goldE{+20}$ * $\blueD{-20}x\greenD{+40}=\maroonD{-20}x\goldE{+20}$

In the following equations, $\blueD{a}$ is equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ is different from $\goldE{d}$.  * $\blueD{-60}x\greenD{+32}=\maroonD{-60}x\goldE{+60}$ * $\blueD{-60}x\greenD{+32}=\maroonD{-60}x\goldE{-32}$    So, the equations have no solutions.
The answer:  * $\blueD{-60}x\greenD{+32}=\maroonD{-60}x\goldE{+60}$ * $\blueD{-60}x\greenD{+32}=\maroonD{-60}x\goldE{-32}$

question.content: **Which of the following equations have infinitely many solutions?**

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have infinitely many solutions, $\blueD{a}$ must be equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ must be equal to $\goldE{d}$.

In the following equation, $\blueD{a}$ is equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ is equal to $\goldE{d}$.  * $\blueD{-6}x\greenD{+35}=\maroonD{-6}x\goldE{+35}$    So, the equation has infinitely many solutions.
The answer:  * $\blueD{-6}x\greenD{+35}=\maroonD{-6}x\goldE{+35}$

question.content: **Which of the following equations have infinitely many solutions?**

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have infinitely many solutions, $\blueD{a}$ must be equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ must be equal to $\goldE{d}$.

In the following equations, $\blueD{a}$ is equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ is equal to $\goldE{d}$.  * $\blueD{-76}x\greenD{+76}=\maroonD{-76}x\goldE{+76}$ * $\blueD{76}x\greenD{+76}=\maroonD{76}x\goldE{+76}$    So, the equations have infinitely many solutions.
The answer:  * $\blueD{-76}x\greenD{+76}=\maroonD{-76}x\goldE{+76}$ * $\blueD{76}x\greenD{+76}=\maroonD{76}x\goldE{+76}$

question.content: **Which of the following equations have infinitely many solutions?**

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have infinitely many solutions, $\blueD{a}$ must be equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ must be equal to $\goldE{d}$.

In the following equations, $\blueD{a}$ is equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ is equal to $\goldE{d}$.  * $\blueD{-19}x\greenD{-19}=\maroonD{-19}x\goldE{-19}$ * $\blueD{-19}x\greenD{+91}=\maroonD{-19}x\goldE{+91}$ * $\blueD{-19}x\greenD{-38}=\maroonD{-19}x\goldE{-38}$    So, the equations have infinitely many solutions.
The answer:  * $\blueD{-19}x\greenD{-19}=\maroonD{-19}x\goldE{-19}$ * $\blueD{-19}x\greenD{+91}=\maroonD{-19}x\goldE{+91}$ * $\blueD{-19}x\greenD{-38}=\maroonD{-19}x\goldE{-38}$

question.content: **Which of the following equations have infinitely many solutions?**

hints.content: An equation of the form $\blueD{a}x+\greenD{b}=\maroonD{c}x+\goldE{d}$ has:  - exactly one solution when $\blueD{a}\neq \maroonD{c}$  - no solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}\neq \goldE{d}$  - infinitely many solutions when $\blueD{a}=\maroonD{c}$ and $\greenD{b}=\goldE{d}$
In order for our equation to have infinitely many solutions, $\blueD{a}$ must be equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ must be equal to $\goldE{d}$.

In the following equations, $\blueD{a}$ is equal to $\maroonD{c}$, and $\greenD{b}$ is equal to $\goldE{d}$.  * $\blueD{37}x\greenD{-37}=\maroonD{37}x\goldE{-37}$ * $x\greenD{-37}=x\goldE{-37}$ * $\blueD{73}x\greenD{-37}=\maroonD{73}x\goldE{-37}$ * $\blueD{74}x\greenD{-37}=\maroonD{74}x\goldE{-37}$    So, the equations have infinitely many solutions.

The answer:  * $\blueD{37}x\greenD{-37}=\maroonD{37}x\goldE{-37}$ * $x\greenD{-37}=x\goldE{-37}$ * $\blueD{73}x\greenD{-37}=\maroonD{73}x\goldE{-37}$ * $\blueD{74}x\greenD{-37}=\maroonD{74}x\goldE{-37}$

The answer:  * $\blueD{46}x\greenD{+23}=\maroonD{46}x+\goldE{23}$
